content: Initial steps for newly diagnosed HIV-positive patients

children.content: ELISA to screen for chronic infection
If acute infection suspected, order ELISA and HIV viral load
Comorbidities, especially cardiovascular disease or risks
Headache, visual changes, focal paresthesia, focal weakness, confusion
Cough, shortness of breath, sputum production
Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, dysphagia, odynophagia, diarrhea, hematochezia
Dysuria, genital discharge, genital itching, genital ulcer or rash
Genital and anal lesions or discharge
HIV genotype assay for drug resistance
Liver function tests, creatinine, electrolytes, fasting glucose
Serology for hepatitis A, B, C, Toxoplasma gondii, varicella, CMV
Integrate history, physical examination, and laboratory tests to determine
Possible presence of active opportunistic infections
Need for active treatment against opportunistic infections, prophylaxis, and/or antiretroviral therapy
Contingent upon CD4 count and prior infections
Pneumococcal vaccine (often deferred until CD4 count >200 cells/mm³)
Hepatitis A (for patients who practice anal intercourse or international travelers) contingent upon CD4 count and prior infections
Tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis boosters
Decision to treat based on clinical status, history of opportunistic infections, CD4 counts, and viral load
Treatment thresholds and recommended agents change frequently
Refer patient to an HIV specialist or refer to www.aidsinfo.nih.gov for the latest recommendations
Repeat CD4 count and viral load 2–8 wk following treatment initiation
